definitions.definition: To start (a fire).
definitions.example: We lit the fire to get some heat.

definitions.definition: To set fire to; to set burning.
To illuminate; to provide light for when it is dark.
definitions.example: I used my torch to light the way home through the woods in the night.

definitions.definition: To become ignited; to take fire.
definitions.example: This soggy match will not light.

definitions.definition: To attend or conduct with a light; to show the way to by means of a light.
To make (a bonus) available to be collected by hitting a target, and thus light up the feature light corresponding to that bonus to indicate its availability.
definitions.example: Light the extra ball by amassing 500 million points in the wizard mode.

definitions.definition: To find by chance.
definitions.example: I lit upon a rare book in a second-hand bookseller's.

definitions.definition: To stop upon (of eyes or a glance); to notice
To alight; to land or come down.
definitions.example: She fell out of the window but luckily lit on her feet.

definitions.definition: To run or light (alight).
Illuminated.
definitions.example: He walked down the lit corridor.

definitions.definition: Intoxicated or under the influence of drugs.
Sexually aroused (usually of a female), especially visibly sexually aroused.
Exciting, captivating; fun.
definitions.example: This party is gonna be lit.

definitions.definition: Excellent, fantastic; cool.
Little.
Little.
Colour; blee; dye; stain.
To colour; dye.
The body of all written works.
The collected creative writing of a nation, people, group or culture.
(usually preceded by the) All the papers, treatises etc. published in academic journals on a particular subject.
Written fiction of a high standard.
definitions.example: However, even “literary” science fiction rarely qualifies as literature, because it treats characters as sets of traits rather than as fully realized human beings with unique life stories. —Adam Cadre, 2008
